channel.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News Today: Read the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Georgia's governing party picks former soccer player as presidential candidate
item.description: Georgia's ruling party, Georgian Dream, nominated ex-soccer star Mikheil Kavelashvili for president amidst post-election controversy. The opposition boycotts parliament, alleging a rigged vote influenced by Russia. Kavelashvili, a former Manchester City player and author of controversial legislation, is expected to win the largely ceremonial role given the ruling party's control.

item.title: ICC prosecutor seeks arrest warrant for Myanmar's military leader over crimes against Rohingya Muslim minority
item.description: The International Criminal Court (ICC) seeks an arrest warrant for Myanmar's military chief, Min Aung Hlaing, over atrocities against the Rohingya Muslim minority. Hlaing, who orchestrated the 2021 coup, faces accusations of crimes against humanity, including deportation and persecution. Nearly a million Rohingya fled to Bangladesh amidst a brutal campaign of ethnic cleansing.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris presidential campaign hit a roadblock when internet show 'Hot Ones' declined interview request
item.description: Kamala Harris's presidential campaign faced difficulties connecting with non-political audiences. Popular platforms like "Hot Ones" declined interview requests, citing a no-politics policy. While Donald Trump engaged with shows like "The Joe Rogan Experience" and others, Harris's team struggled to secure similar opportunities, hindering their outreach efforts and potentially contributing to their election loss.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump unveils key picks for his second term: John Phelan, Kevin Hassett, and Vince Haley appointed to top roles
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump announced key appointments for his upcoming administration. Businessman John Phelan will lead the Navy, economist Kevin Hassett will chair the National Economic Council, and speechwriter Vince Haley will head the Domestic Policy Council. These choices signal Trump's focus on his "America First" agenda and reliance on trusted allies.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 1 dead, several injured as South Korea hit by worst November snowstorm
item.description: South Korea was hit by its heaviest November snowstorm in over five decades on Wednesday, blanketing Seoul with up to 20 centimeters of snow. This unprecedented snowfall caused widespread travel disruptions, grounding flights, halting ferries, and closing hiking trails. The storm impacted central, eastern, and southwestern regions, with accumulations reaching 23 centimeters.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Pakistan: Imran Khan's PTI calls off Islamabad protest after government crackdown
item.description: Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) called off its Islamabad protest after a police crackdown dispersed demonstrators from the Red Zone. Party leaders, including Khyber Pakhtunkhwa chief minister and Imran Khan's wife, left the protest site. The PTI cited government brutality as the reason for suspending the protest, which initially aimed to secure Imran Khan's release from jail.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'India, US stronger when working together,' says US secretary of state Antony Blinken
item.description: Top diplomats Blinken and Jaishankar met in Italy. They discussed global security and the growing US-India partnership. Both nations want to promote a free and open Indo-Pacific. They also talked about technology, clean energy, and investment opportunities. Jaishankar mentioned the Quad's evolution and Indo-Pacific dynamics. He looks forward to welcoming Blinken to India in 2025.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Donald Trump names lawyer Jamieson Greer his US trade envoy
item.description: Donald Trump on Tuesday named Jamieson Greer his trade envoy, a key figure in implementing the president-elect's economic agenda, particularly his plans to use tariffs to raise revenue and help bring more manufacturing to US shores. The aim is to raise government revenue and target countries he said have been "ripping us off," while pushing businesses to bring production back to US shores.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'A great step': Australia's House of Representatives passes bill to ban children under 16 from social media
item.description: Australia's House of Representatives passed a bill banning children under 16 from social media. Platforms like TikTok and Facebook could face hefty fines for non-compliance. While facing criticism regarding privacy and parental control, the bill aims to protect children online and is expected to pass the Senate. Supporters believe it's a crucial step in ensuring children's online safety.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Special Counsel Jack Smith's investigation into Trump costs taxpayers over $50 million: Report
item.description: Special Counsel Jack Smith's investigation into former President Donald Trump has incurred costs nearing $50 million. The investigation focused on Trump's handling of classified documents and attempts to overturn the 2020 election. However, Trump's 2024 election victory paused the legal proceedings due to Justice Department rules.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah reach ceasefire deal for Lebanon: What are the terms of agreement?
item.description: Israel and Hezbollah agreed to a ceasefire in Lebanon. Israeli troops and Hezbollah will withdraw. UN peacekeepers will deploy. The US will lead an international monitoring group. The Gaza conflict is not part of this agreement. Hezbollah's support depends on Israel halting attacks.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris' Team: 'Price paid' for short campaign against Donald Trump
item.description: Kamala Harris's campaign leadership attributed their loss to Donald Trump primarily to the short 107-day campaign period following Biden's withdrawal. They defended their strategic choices on "Pod Save America," including their approach to Republican voters and the decision not to counter Trump's attack on Harris's stance on transgender inmate surgeries, despite acknowledging its effectiveness.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: FBI agent uses free tattoo, modeling promise to lure, sexually assault victims, says police
item.description: An FBI agent, Eduardo Valdivia, using aliases, has been accused of sexually assaulting two women in Maryland. He allegedly lured them via Instagram with promises of tattoos and modeling work, then assaulted them during photo shoots. Valdivia's lawyer claims the interactions were consensual.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US' largest trade partners Mexico, Canada and China respond to Trump's tariff threat
item.description: President-elect Trump has announced plans to impose tariffs on goods from Mexico, Canada, and China, citing concerns over fentanyl, illegal drugs, and migration. The move has drawn sharp criticism from all three countries, with leaders warning of economic damage and retaliatory measures.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire: What it means for Lebanonâ€™s future
item.description: A US-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah is set to begin, halting over a year of fighting. The deal involves Israeli troop withdrawals and Hezbollah's retreat north of the Litani River, with UN peacekeepers deployed. While offering a reprieve, the agreement's fragility is underscored by the unresolved Gaza conflict and the broader Palestinian question.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Submerged car, human remains found in Georgia pond may solve 1980 New York couple disappearance
item.description: A submerged car found in a Georgia pond may solve the 44-year-old mystery of a missing New York couple. The vehicle matches the description of the car belonging to Charles and Catherine Romer, who disappeared in 1980. Personal belongings and a human bone were discovered inside, offering potential closure to their family.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US: Uber Eats burrito delivery turns out to be marijuana
item.description: An Uber Eats driver in New Jersey smelled something unusual during a delivery. She called the police. The package contained marijuana disguised as a burrito. Police are investigating the incident. The drugs were seized. Uber praised the driver's actions. This follows a similar incident involving fraudulent gift cards.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Scientists find new formula that could help detect killer asteroids
item.description: Spanish scientists have developed a groundbreaking formula using the gravitational bending of light to pinpoint celestial objects, including potentially dangerous asteroids. This enhances asteroid orbit prediction and planetary defence systems like Nasa's DART.
item.dc:creator: TOI Science Desk

item.title: Texas offers land for Trump deportation centres, names initiative after slain girl Jocelyn Nungaray
item.description: Texas proposed land for deportation centers, named "Jocelyn Initiative," after a girl allegedly killed by illegal immigrants. The initiative aims to expedite deportations of violent criminal migrants upon Trump's potential return to office. Texas offered land and resources, with Trump's team confirming their intent to utilize them, potentially with military assistance.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Did Kamala Harris campaign blame Biden for election loss? 'Price to be paid for...'
item.description: Kamala Harris' campaign chair, Jen O'Malley Dillon, in her first interview since the election defeat said it was a bulls**t notion that Harris was scared of interviews. The Harris campaign said the election result was the price to be paid for their shortened campaign, indirectly holding Joe Biden responsible for the defeat. The campaign didn't acknowledge any mistake on their part and said they just had less time.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
